704403f-b.title: Brooklyn: Flushing Avenue - Cypress Avenue
704403f-b.text:
1325 Flushing Ave., north side, between Cypress Ave., and Seneoa
Avenue,showing in a set of four views the Nicholas Wyckoff house, also
kn9wn as the Peter Wyckoff home. Views 1 and 2 are the same. No. 3 is
a rear view, looking southwest towards Flushing Ave. No. 4 is a partial
view of No. 2. Peter Wyckoff occupied this house during the Revolutionary
War. Prior to this, in 1765, it was the Schenck farmhouse. In that year
Nicholas Ayckoff acquired possession. Eugene L. Armbruster states that
a broad hall runs through the center of the house, on the left side of the
hall is a parlor and sitting room. On the other side of the hall is a
dining room, kitchen, and three bedrooms. In the sitting room is a colonial
mantle piece, having pictures of the old Rapelye, Johnson, and Wyckoff
houses. The upper floors contain eight rooms and a garret. In a corner of
the hall is an ancient arandfather clock still keeping time. See other
09.  views for more data. For ore data see the N.Y. Sun, Februarv 18,
September 1928.
Views 1 \& 4.
Views 2 \& 3: 1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

704401f-a.title: Brooklyn: Flushing Avenue - Cypress Avenue
704401f-a.folder: Flushing Avenue & Cypress Avenue, Brooklyn, NY

704402f-a.title: Brooklyn: Flushing Avenue - Cypress Avenue
704402f-a.text:
(1)
1325 Flushing Ave., north side, east of Cypress Ave., showing in
the foreground, the Nicholas Wyckoff farmhouse, accuired in 1765; from
a Schenck. Another Nicholas Wyckoff was owner from 1852-1860. For more
data see the N.Y. Sun. February 18, 19  1666.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, looking south, showing a rear view of the out-buildings
of the farmhouse.
September 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(3)
The same, showing another angle. Note that one of the barns is
partially demolished by fire.
September 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(4)
The same, showing another close up of the barn. It was erected in
1650 or 1656 (marked on rafter) and partially demolished by fire in
1700. The original joists remained and the barn oas rebuilt around them.
It was again partially destroyed by fire in March 1922.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
